[214166/1]   
OAH No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC No. E -015/PA -24-198 
 
STATE OF MINNESOTA  
OFFICE OF ADMINISTRATIVE HEARINGS  
 
FOR THE MINNESOTA PUBLIC UTILITIES COMMISSION  
 
In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota 
Power for Acquisition of ALLLETE by 
Canada Pension Plan Investment Board 
and Global Infrastructure Partners  EXHIBIT A  
PROTECTIVE ORDER FOR HIGHLY 
CONFIDENTIAL TRADE SECRET DATA  
By my signature below, I acknowledge that I have read the attached Protective 
Order for Highly Confidential Trade Secret Data dated December 5 , 2024  in Minnesota 
Public Utilities Commission Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 and OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -
40339 , and understand and agree to be bound by all of its terms.  
Without limiting the generality of the foregoing, I agree not to disclose to any person 
or entity not authorized to receive materials designated “HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL 
TRADE SECRET INFORMATION”  under the terms of the Protective Order for Highly 
Confidential Trade Secret Data, or any copies or extracts of information derived 
therefrom, which have been disclosed to me. I further agree to use any materials 
disclosed to me solely for the purpose of t his proceeding and for no other purpose.  
I submit myself to the jurisdiction of the Minnesota Office of Administrative 
Hearings and the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission for the purpose of enforcing the 
Protective Order for Highly Confidential Trade Secret Data.

content: OAH 25-2500-40339MPUC E015/PA-24-198STATE OF MINNESOTAOFFICE OF ADMINISTRATIVE HEARINGSFOR THE PUBLIC UTILITIES COMMISSIONIn the Matter of the Petition of MinnesotaPower for Acquisition of ALLETE byCanada Pension Plan Investment Boardand Global Infrastructure PartnersORDER GRANTING PETITION TOINTERVENE OF THE SIERRA CLUBThis matter is pending before Administrative Law Judge Megan J. McKenzie uponthe Petition to Intervene (Petition) submitted by the Sierra Club filed on November 15,2024. A related motion for the pro hac vice admission of Sierra Club’s attorneys KristinHenry and Patrick Woolsey was filed December 5, 2024. No objections to the Petition orthe motion were received.Based upon the files and record in this matter, pursuant to Minn. R. 1400.6200(2023), and for the reasons expressed in the attached Memorandum,IT IS HEREBY ORDERED:1. The Sierra Club’s Petition is GRANTED.2. The Sierra Club shall participate in these proceedings as a full party.3. The pro hac vice motions of Kristin Henry and Patrick Woolsey areGRANTED.Dated: December 19, 2024MEGAN J. McKENZIEAdministrative Law Judge[214307/1] 2MEMORANDUMThe Minnesota Public Utilities Commission (Commission) referred this matter tothe Office of Administrative Hearings for a contested case proceeding initiated by apetition of ALLETE, Inc., owner of Minnesota Power, seeking approval for MinnesotaPower to be acquired by entities controlled by the Canada Pension Plan InvestmentBoard (CPP Investments). The Commission designated the parties in this matter, grantedcertain motions to intervene, and further noted that other persons wishing to becomeformal parties should promptly file a petition to intervene.The Sierra Club is a national nonprofit environmental organization working topromote safe and healthy communities, protect and improve air and water quality in theUnited States, limit the adverse effects of climate change, and promote the transition toclean energy. The Sierra Club has over 14,000 members in Minnesota, many of whomare Minnesota Power customers, and has consistently advocated for Minnesota Powerto transition away from fossil-fueled electricity generation. The Sierra Club hasparticipated in matters before the Commission and asks to intervene as full party in thismatter to represent the interests of their members and constituencies. The Sierra Clubintends to participate fully in the development of a factual and legal record in this case,including through submission of expert testimony, cross-examination of witnesses, andfiling of briefs.1Intervention in a contested case proceeding is governed by Minn. R. 1400.6200.Under that rule, a person seeking to intervene in a contested case must show:(1) how the petitioner’s legal rights, duties, or privileges may bedetermined or affected by the contested case;(2) how the petitioner may be directly affected by the outcome of thecase or that petitioner’s participation is authorized by statute, rule, orcourt decision;(3) the grounds and purposes for which intervention is sought; and(4) petitioner’s statutory right to intervene if one should exist.2The presiding administrative law judge shall allow intervention if the petitionerestablishes these elements, unless the judge finds that petitioner’s interests areadequately represented by one or more parties already participating in the case.3 Further,the administrative law judge must specify the extent of the petitioner’s participation, asthe rule allows for limited or full intervention.4 Under Minn. R. 1400.6200, subp. 3(A)-(C),an intervenor may be allowed to: (1) file a written brief without acquiring the status of a1 Document 202411-212020-01.2 Minn. R. 1400.6200, subp. 1.3Id., subp. 3.4Id.[214307/1] 3party; (2) intervene as a party with all the rights of a party; or (3) intervene as a party withall the rights of a party but limited to specific issues and to the means necessary to presentand develop those issues.The Sierra Club has established it should be permitted to intervene as a party. TheSierra Club is focused on protecting the rights and welfare of their members and has aspecific tie to Minnesota based on their members in the state. While there is some overlapbetween the interests of the Sierra Club and other parties, their interests are not identical,and the Sierra Club will provide an important perspective in this proceeding. No otherparty adequately represents the Sierra Club’s interests, and no person objected to itsPetition. The Sierra Club participation as a party will further the development of a robustfactual and legal record for the Commission to consider in this matter.Furthermore, Kristin Henry and Patrick Woolsey have demonstrated that they areadmitted to practice law in the bar of another state and are in good standing with nodiscipline concerns. They will therefore be allowed to represent the Sierra Club in thismatter.For these reasons, the Petition is GRANTED. The Sierra Club will be permitted toparticipate in this matter as a full party, with all of the rights and duties of a party.Additionally, Kristin Henry and Patrick Woolsey’s motions for admission pro hac vice areGRANTED.M. J. M.OAH 25-2500-40339MPUC E015/PA-24-198STATE OF MINNESOTAOFFICE OF ADMINISTRATIVE HEARINGSFOR THE PUBLIC UTILITIES COMMISSIONIn the Matter of the Petition of MinnesotaPower for Acquisition of ALLETE byCanada Pension Plan Investment Boardand Global Infrastructure PartnersORDER GRANTING PETITION TOINTERVENE OF THE UNION OFOPERATING ENGINEERS LOCAL 49AND NORTH CENTRAL STATESREGIONAL COUNCIL OFCARPENTERSThis matter is pending before Administrative Law Judge Megan J. McKenzie uponthe Petition to Intervene (Petition) submitted by the Union of Operating EngineersLocal 49 (Local 49) and North Central States Regional Council of Carpenters (NCSRCC)filed on November 15, 2024. No objections to the Petition were received.Based upon the files and record in this matter, pursuant to Minn. R. 1400.6200(2023), and for the reasons expressed in the attached Memorandum,IT IS HEREBY ORDERED:1. Local 49 and NCSRCC’s Petition is GRANTED.2. Local 49 and NCSRCC shall participate in these proceedings as a full party.Dated: December 19, 2024MEGAN J. McKENZIEAdministrative Law JudgeMEMORANDUMThe Minnesota Public Utilities Commission (Commission) referred this matter tothe Office of Administrative Hearings for a contested case proceeding initiated by apetition of ALLETE, Inc., owner of Minnesota Power, seeking approval for MinnesotaPower to be acquired by entities controlled by the Canada Pension Plan InvestmentBoard (CPP Investments). The Commission designated the parties in this matter, granted [214306/1] 2certain motions to intervene, and further noted that other persons wishing to becomeformal parties should promptly file a petition to intervene.Local 49 and NCSRCC are labor organizations representing Minnesota workers.Local 49 represents more than 12,000 construction workers and public employees inMinnesota and NCSRCC represents more than 12,000 construction workers inMinnesota. Both unions represent workers who build, maintain and repair portions ofMinnesota Power’s energy infrastructure on behalf of union-signatory contractors.Local 49 and NCSRCC have participated in matters before the Commission have theirprincipal places of business in Minnesota. Local 49 and NCSRCC ask to intervene as fullparty in this matter to represent the interests of their members and constituencies.1Intervention in a contested case proceeding is governed by Minn. R. 1400.6200.Under that rule, a person seeking to intervene in a contested case must show:(1) how the petitioner’s legal rights, duties, or privileges may bedetermined or affected by the contested case;(2) how the petitioner may be directly affected by the outcome of thecase or that petitioner’s participation is authorized by statute, rule, orcourt decision;(3) the grounds and purposes for which intervention is sought; and(4) petitioner’s statutory right to intervene if one should exist.2The presiding administrative law judge shall allow intervention if the petitionerestablishes these elements, unless the judge finds that petitioner’s interests areadequately represented by one or more parties already participating in the case.3 Further,the administrative law judge must specify the extent of the petitioner’s participation, asthe rule allows for limited or full intervention.4 Under Minn. R. 1400.6200, subp. 3(A)-(C),an intervenor may be allowed to: (1) file a written brief without acquiring the status of aparty; (2) intervene as a party with all the rights of a party; or (3) intervene as a party withall the rights of a party but limited to specific issues and to the means necessary to presentand develop those issues.Local 49 and NCSRCC have established they should be permitted to intervene asparties. Local 49 and NCSRCC are focused on protecting the rights and welfare of theirmembers. Local 49 and NCSRCC have a specific tie to Minnesota based on theirmembers in the state. While there is some overlap between the interests of the Local 49and NCSRCC and IBEW and LUINA, their interests are not identical, and the Local 49and NCSRCC will provide an important perspective in this proceeding. No other party1 See Doc. 202411-211967-02.2 Minn. R. 1400.6200, subp. 1.3Id., subp. 3.4Id.[214306/1] 3adequately represents the Local 49 and NCSRCC’s interests, and no person objected toits Petition. Local 49 and NCSRCC’s participation as a party will further the developmentof a robust factual and legal record for the Commission to consider in this matter.For these reasons, the Petition is GRANTED. Local 49 and NCSRCC will bepermitted to participate in this matter as full parties, with all of the rights and duties of aparty.M. J. content:
OAH No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC E015/PA -24-198 
STATE OF MINNESOTA  
OFFICE OF ADMINISTRATIVE HEARINGS  
FOR THE PUBLIC UTILITIES COMMISSION  
 
In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota 
Power for Acquisition of ALLETE by Canada 
Pension Plan Investment Board and Global 
Infrastructure Partners  
  
PROTECTIVE ORDER  
FOR HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL  
TRADE SECRET DATA  
This matter came before Administrative Law Judge Megan J. McKenzie upon the 
joint request of the parties and participants to the October 21, 2024 prehearing conference.  
David R. Moeller, Senior Regulatory Counsel, Minnesota Power, and Elizabeth M. 
Brama and Kodi J. Verhalen, Taft Stettinius & Hollister LLP, appeared on behalf of the 
Applicant, ALLETE, Inc. d/b/a Minnesota Power (Minnesota Power or the Company).  
Ryan Barlow and Dan Lipschultz, Moss and Barnett, appeared on behalf of 
Applicants Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and Global Infrastructure Partners 
(CPP -GIP).  
Katherine Arnold and Greg Merz, Assistant Attorneys General, appeared on behalf 
of the Minnesota Department of Commerce, Division of Energy Resources (DOC).  
Peter Scholtz, Assistant Attorney General, appeared on behalf of the Office of the 
Attorney General – Residential Utilities Division (OAG -RUD).  
Andrew Moratzka, Amber S. Lee, and Eden Fauré, Stoel Rives, LLP, appeared on 
behalf of the Large Power Intervenors (LPI).  
Hudson Kingston, Attorney, appeared on behalf of CURE.  
George Shardlow, Executive Director, participated on behalf of the Energy CENTS 
Coalition (ECC).  
Brian Edstrom , Attorney, appeared  on behalf of the Citizens Utility Board of 
Minnesota (CUB).  
Kristin Renskers, Will Keyes, and Eric Berube, Business Representatives, 
participated on behalf of IBEW Local 31 (IBEW).  
 
[214166/1]  2 
 Jorge Alonso and Robert Manning participated on behalf of the Minnesota Public 
Utilities Commission (Commission) staff.  
BACKGROUND  
On December 5 , 2024, Administrative Law Judge Megan J. McKenzie issued a 
Protective Order in this proceeding. Paragraph 21 of the Protective Order addresses the 
possibility that the parties might request protection for information that is highly confidential 
and trade secret. The Order provided:  
Highly Confidential Information : During the proceeding in this matter, parties 
may request protected data that is also highly confidential information. Highly 
confidential information is protected data that would benefit the receiving party 
or any other party to this proceeding in its b usiness operations. The first page 
and individual pages of a document determined in good faith to include highly 
confidential trade secret information must be marked “NOT PUBLIC 
DOCUMENT – HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL TRADE SECRET 
INFORMATION.” If such highly confidential information is requested, any 
party may request heightened protective measures as necessary regarding the 
disclosure of the highly confidential information, including, but not limited to, 
identifying particular party representat ives who are eligible to receive highly 
confidential information and limiting the use of the highly confidential 
information.  Such additional protections shall be in addition to, and not in lieu 
of, the protections set forth in this Protective Order.  
In order to address the parties’ need to exchange highly confidential information in 
this matter, as well as the need to limit access to some data as between the parties to the 
Acquisition and in case of any other unforeseen limitation, pursuant to the additional 
agreement of the parties, and based upon the files and record in this matter,  
IT IS HEREBY ORDERED:  
1. Purpose . The purpose of this Protective Order for Highly Confidential Trade 
Secret Data (HCTS Protective Order) is to facilitate the disclosure of highly confidential 
information. Access to and review of Highly Confidential Trade Secret information shall 
be controlled by the terms of this HCTS Protective Order.  
2. Pursuant to Minn. Stat. § 13.03, subd. 6  (2024) , and the files and 
proceedings herein, the Administrative Law Judge finds that data that is classified as not 
public in the possession of the government agencies may be discoverable in this 
regulatory action only and that the benefit to the parties of the  government agencies’ 
disclosing discoverable not public data pursuant to this HCTS Protective Order in this 
regulatory action only outweighs any harm to the confidentiality interests of the 
government agencie s maintaining the data, or of any person who has provided the data 
or who is the subject of the data, or to the privacy interest of an individual identified in the 
data. To be clear, the purpose of this provision is to facilitate the exchange of testimony 
and discovery between parties permitted to intervene in this proceeding, representatives 
 
[214166/1]  3 
 of whom have executed Exhibit  A, as applicable. By executing Exhibit A, no party is 
presumed to be waiving any right to object to the production of not public data in any 
forum outside of this specific proceeding.  
3. Definition of Highly Confidential Trade Secret Information . The term Highly 
Confidential Trade Secret Information (HCTS) Information shall mean all information , 
related to: 
a) commercial arrangements or agreements that may affect future 
negotiations or transactions of the disclosing party ; 
b) commercially sensitive investment, financing, or forward -looking business 
plans , analysis, and/or models  by or for a disclosing party;  
c) commercially sensitive data related to specific customers or customer 
groups ; or, 
d) commercially sensitive proprietary information of entities other than the 
disclosing party .   
4. Government Agencies . The government agencies with access to HCTS 
Information,  which include the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission, the Office of 
Administrative Hearings, the Office of the Attorney General, the Minnesota Department of 
Commerce, and the Minnesota Department of Administration (Government Agencies) are 
subject to va rious laws and rules, including the Minnesota Government Data Practices Act, 
the records retention requirements of Minn. Stat. §§ 138.163 -.226 (202 4), as well as agency 
specific rules and procedures. Due to the potential for conflict with thes e laws and rules, 
the government agencies identified above are not subject to paragraphs 8 and 1 5 of this 
HCTS Order.  
5. Parties . Parties shall include Minnesota Power, CPP-GIP, DOC, OAG -RUD, 
LPI, CURE, ECC, CUB, IBEW, and the Laborers District Council of Minnesota and North 
Dakota (LIUNA).  
6. Designation of HCTS Information . The parties may designate certain 
competitively sensitive Trade Secret Information HCTS Information if they determine in 
good faith that the information falls within the above definition of HCTS Information. 
Parties must scrutinize carefully responsive docume nts and information and limit their 
designations as HCTS Information to information that truly might impose a serious 
business risk if disseminated without the heightened protections provided in this section.   
The design ating party shall limit the HCTS designation to those portions of the document 
that meet the definition of HCTS Information.   
7. Marking HCTS Information . The first page and individual pages of a 
document determined in good faith to include HCTS Information must be marked to read: 
“NOT PUBLIC DOCUMENT - CONTAINS HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL TRADE SECRET 
INFORMATION .”  Each page that contains HCTS Information must be marked separately 
to indicate HCTS Information, even where that information has been redacted.    
 
[214166/1]  4 
 8. Access to HCTS Information . The HCTS Information can be shared with the 
Government Agencies. In addition, after signing Exhibit A to this HCTS Order, the HCTS 
Information can be shared with outside counsel and retained consultants of the Parties 
and Government Agencies (collectively, Pa rty Representatives) and court reporters, but 
cannot be shared with the other employees of any receiving Party or Parties other than 
the disclosing party or parties . If a Party does not have external counsel, a Party may 
designate an internal attorney (or if none, an internal representative) as a Party 
Representative in lieu of outside counsel.  If a Party does not have outside consultants, a 
Party may designate an employee working with and under the supervision of counsel  as 
a Party Representative . 
Parties shall make a good faith effort to limit the number of ind ividuals who have 
access to HCTS Information to no more than two individuals.  
9. Custody . Party  Representatives will securely maintain the documents and 
any notes reflecting their contents  by means appropriate to the medium and shall be 
handled by the recipient in a manner suitable to protect its confidentiality  consistent with 
the requirements of this HCTS Protective Order . Unless specifically addressed in this 
section, all other sections of the Protective Order applicable to Trade Secret Information 
also apply to HCTS Information . 
10. Objection to Admissibility . The furnishing of any document, data, study or 
other materials pursuant to this HCTS Order shall in no way limit the right of a party to 
object to its relevance or admissibility in proceedings before the Commission or the 
Administrative Law Judge.  
11.  Challenge to Confidentiality . This HCTS Order establishes a procedure for 
the expeditious handling of information that parties claim is HCTS Information. It shall not 
be construed as an agreement or ruling on the confidentiality of any document. Any party 
may challenge the characteri zation of any information, document, data or study claimed 
to be confidential in the following manner:  
a) A party seeking to challenge the confidentiality of any materials pursuant to 
this HCTS Order shall first contact counsel for the party claiming HCTS and 
attempt to resolve any differences by stipulation;  
b) In the event that  the Parties cannot agree as to the character of the 
information challenged, any party challenging the confidentiality shall do so 
by appropriate pleading. This pleading shall: (1) designate the document, 
transcript or other material challenged in a manner  that will specifically 
isolate the challenged material from other material claimed as confidential; 
and (2) state with specificity the grounds upon which the documents, 
transcript or other material are deemed to be nonconfidential by the 
challenging party . The party that provided the challenged information shall 
be provided the opportunity to respond to the pleading.  
c) A ruling on the confidentiality of the challenged information, document, data 
or study shall be made by the Administrative Law Judge after proceedings 
 
[214166/1]  5 
 in camera , which shall be conducted under circumstances such that only 
those persons duly authorized hereunder to have access to such 
confidential materials shall be present.  
d) In the event of a challenge to the designation of HCTS, the party making 
that designation has the burden to prove that the information meets the 
HCTS definition.  
e) The HCTS portions of the transcript of said in camera hearing shall be 
marked by the court reporter as “NOT  PUBLIC DOCUMENT  - HIGHLY 
CONFIDENTIAL TRADE SECRET INFORMATION”  
f) In the event that the Administrative Law Judge should rule that any information, 
document, data or study should be removed from the restrictions imposed by 
this HCTS Order, no party shall disclose such information, document, data or 
study or use it in the public record for five (5) days unless  authorized by the 
party claiming HCTS to do so. The provisions of this subsection are intended 
to enable the party claiming HCTS information to seek a stay or other relief 
from an order removing the restriction of this HCTS Order from materials 
claimed to  be confidential.  
12. Receipt into Evidence at Hearings . Provision is hereby made for receipt  into 
evidence at the evidentiary hearing in this proceeding materials claimed to be HCTS in 
the following manner:  
a) Prior to the use of or substantive reference to any HCTS Information in 
argument or live witness questioning at the evidentiary hearing, the Parties 
intending to use such information shall make that intention known to the other 
Parties.  
b) The Parties shall make a good -faith effort to reach an agreement so the 
argument or live witness questioning of HCTS Information at the evidentiary 
hearing can be used in a manner which will not reveal the HCTS -designated 
information .  This may include alternatives to use of the HCTS Information 
in the record, including but not limited to potential stipulation to a fact rather 
than use of the HCTS information itself, if mutually agreeable to the Parties.  
c) If such efforts fail, the Parties shall separately identify which portions, if any, 
of the documents to be referenced that are not already pre -filed in the HCTS 
docket, Docket No.  M-24-383, shall be submitted in a manner that limits 
disclosure to persons permitted access to HCTS Information , and shall notify 
the Administrative Law Judge of the HCTS Information.  
13. In Camera  Hearing . Any HCTS Information that must be orally discussed  to 
be placed in the sealed record in the proceeding shall be offered in an in camera hearing, 
attended only by persons authorized to have access to the information. Similarly, any 
cross -examination on or substantive reference to HCTS Information (or that portion of the 
 
[214166/1]  6 
 
record containing HCTS Information or references thereto) shall be received in an in 
camera hearing and shall be marked and treated as provided herein . 
14. Pleadings . Where reference to HCTS Information is required in the 
pleadings, briefs, arguments or motions, it shall be by citation of title or exhibit number or 
some other description that will not disclose the substantive HCTS Information contained 
therein. Any us e of or substantive references to HCTS Information shall be placed in a 
separate section of the pleadings to the extent practicable. This HCTS section shall be 
provided only to Party Representatives and Government Agencies and filed in HCTS 
Docket No. M-24-383. 
15. Return . Unless otherwise ordered, HCTS Information in possession of Party 
Representatives, including transcripts of any depositions to which a claim of 
confidentiality is made, shall remain under seal, shall continue to be subject to the 
protective requirements of this HCTS Order, and shall be returned by Party 
Representatives to counsel for the party claiming HCTS protection, or destroyed by the 
receiving party, within thirty (30) days after final settlement or conclusion of the case.  
16. Inadvertent Disclosure . No party shall have waived its right to designate any 
documents, testimony, transcripts, pleadings, briefs, data, information, studies or other 
materials as HCTS Information by inadvertent disclosure, provided the disclosing party 
thereafter gives writte n notice to the recipient(s) or such information that it should have 
been designated as HCTS information. From and after receipt of such notice, the 
previously disclosed information subsequently identified as HCTS Information shall be  
treated as HCTS Information, as applicable, for purposes of this HCTS Order.  
17. Violation .  Any violation of this Protective Order or of the terms of Exhibit A 
shall constitute a violation of an order of the Commission . Each party bears the 
responsibility to ensure that each of its representatives shall perform all obligations under 
this Protective Order. Each party retains the right to seek appropriate legal or equitable 
remedies in the event that any party or its repr esentatives fail to perform any obligations 
under this Protective Order.  
18. Continued Effect . This Protective Order shall continue in full force and effect 
with respect to the Protected Materials provided hereunder after the proceeding is closed.
